info.title: Hornetsecurity API
info.description:
# API Overview

Our REST based API provides a lot of endpoints to communicate directly with our back end. These are the same endpoints
which our front end uses.

Nearly all of our endpoints require authentication. You can make authenticated requests against the Control Panel API by
providing an Authorization token within the headers of your requests or with a cookie. We differentiate between
"login tokens" and "API access tokens":

- **login token**: Obtained by authenticating via the Control Panel. For example with credentials or by using M365 / other SSO providers.
- **API access token**: Obtained by creating an API token for (admin) users within the Control Panel user setting interface.

If you perform authenticated requests against the Control Panel API by using "API access tokens", you are good to go. 
But if you perform authenticated requests using a "login token" or unauthenticated ones, you **have to provide** an App-ID with
your request. This approach is explained further below.


## Using the API

In general the communication with the Control Panel API is done by transmitting and receiving JSON. An example request
using cURL using the most basic endpoint looks like this:

```bash
curl -s --request GET --url "https://cp.hornetsecurity.com/api/v0/version/"
```
```
"6.32.8.14"
```


## Making authenticated API calls

As described above you have to provide a token within your request headers or via cookie to communicate with endpoints
requiring authentication. The provided token authenticates and identifies the user sending requests to the API. 

Every action within the Control Panel is initiated by a requesting user and performed on a selected object. The selected
object refers to our hierarchy of users, customers or partners. Many endpoints are limited to a specific hierarchy
level, but some of them might be capable of working with different object types.

A request is authenticated  by adding the `Authorization` header:

```
Authorization: Token <token>
```

If the Authorization header is present in the request, it is preferred to the `auth_token` cookie.


### Using API access tokens

You can obtain an API access token via the user settings view from within the Control Panel. There you can create new
access tokens for the currently logged in user. These tokens can have an optional expiry date. If not set, they won't
expire until deleted.

Assuming that you have such an API access token, authenticated requests will work exactly like described in the example
above, by providing it via the Authorization header within your request.

Example using an obtained API access token to make authenticated API requests:

```bash
curl --request GET --url 'https://cp.hornetsecurity.com/api/v0/user/' \
     --header 'Authorization: Token 217c386123d1d1751638d0f60857394467fe395f'
```
```json
{
  "id": 14685,
  "name": "user@example.com",
  "path": "example.com/user@example.com"
}
```

### Using login tokens

You can obtain a login token by successfully authenticating within the Control Panel. This token can then be used to
make further requests. If the user can authenticate using plain "username / password" credentials, you can call the
[login](#operation/login_post) API endpoint with these credentials to obtain a valid login token for the given user
identified by the username.

The API call returns a response containing the authorization token. It also sets a cookie named `auth_token` with the
valid token as value.

**Please note:** This is only possible if no other authentication back end is configured for the given user such as M365,
an external IDP or LDAP auth.

```bash
curl --request POST --url 'https://cp.hornetsecurity.com/api/v0/auth/login/' \
     --header 'Content-Type: application/json' \
     --data '{ "username": <username>, "password": <password> }'
```
```json
{"object_id": 801745291, "token": "217c386123d1d1751638d0f60857394467fe395f"}
```

Using login tokens for authenticated requests instead of API access tokens requires an additional header, called `App-ID`.

This App-ID is required to provide context to the application which uses personalized login tokens. This might be
utilized to provide custom rate limits to specific applications or endpoints.

You can obtain such an App-ID by contacting our support. Treat the App-ID as a secret. It is not required if you use
API access tokens as explained above.

Example using an obtained login token in combination with a valid App-ID to make authenticated API requests:

```bash
curl --request GET --url 'https://cp.hornetsecurity.com/api/v0/user/' \
     --header 'App-ID: <app_id>' \
     --header 'Authorization: Token 217c386123d1d1751638d0f60857394467fe395f'
```
```json
{
  "id": 14685,
  "name": "user@example.com",
  "path": "example.com/user@example.com"
}
```


### Disclaimer

**We will block applications or API access tokens temporarily or permanently if they don't use our API respectfully or
abuse it under any means.** 


## Getting info about an object

To request information about an object, you must provide the object_id or the name to be able to identify the object. Then, the response will contain the data of the object.

```bash
curl --request GET --url 'http://cp.hornetsecurity.com/api/v0/object/?object_id=123' \
     --header 'App-ID: <app_id>' \
     --header 'Authorization: Token 217c386123d1d1751638d0f60857394467fe395f' 
```
```json
{"object_id": 138, "name": "gevonne.com"}
```

```bash
curl --request GET --url 'http://cp.hornetsecurity.com/api/v0/object/?name=gevonne.com' \
     --header 'App-ID: <app_id>' \
     --header 'Authorization: Token 217c386123d1d1751638d0f60857394467fe395f'
```
```json
{"object_id": 138, "name": "gevonne.com"}
```

## Changelog

### v0.12.0 (Auto Remediate)
- Deprecated `GET /api/v0/thirdparty/o365/expostdeletion_permission_link/` in favor of `POST /api/v0/thirdparty/o365/autoremediate_permission_link/`

### v0.11.1 (SMIME certificate update)

- regarding SMIME certificate settings available via `POST /api/v0/email_encryption/smime_user_certificates/`
  - in the payload the fields `firstname` and `lastname` have been deprecated and will not be processed anymore
  - in the response
    - the fields `year`, `domain` and `domain_fqdn` have been deprecated
    - the fields `locked` and `cert_activationdate` have been added

### v.0.11.0 (API credentials)
- Remove the need of the `CP-Token` and `App-Version` headers
- Only require the `App-Id` header if the request is authenticated by a login token. If an API token is used, this header is not required anymore.

### v.0.10.1 (Decommission of the NextGenerationWebFilter)
- Remove all the NextGenerationWebFilter-related endpoints

### v.0.10.0 (cookie auth & 403 to 401 for invalid api auth)
- Allow API auth via `auth_token` cookie in addition to the `Authorization` header
- Change the response code for requests with invalid credentials from `403 Forbidden` to `401 Unauthorized` for both header and cookie auth

### v.0.9.0 (Secure Links Statistics removal)
- Removed all endpoints for Secure Links Statistics (`/api/v0/atp/url_rewriting/*`)

### v.0.8.1 (Password restriction security update)
- Changed the minimal allowed value for the minimum length for `POST /api/v0/restrictions/password` from `6` to `8`
- Deprecated all available fields of `POST /api/v0/restrictions/password` except for the `min_length`. These fields will always be interpreted as `True`

### v.0.8.0 (Timezone adjustments)
- Introduced new field `timezone` for user settings endpoints. This field replaces the `location` that was previously used as timezone.
- Merged both `user_settings` endpoints `GET /api/v0/user/settings/` and `POST /api/v0/user/settings/<id>/` into one enpoint `/api/v0/user/settings/`
- These endpoints now use the object_id for fetching the user settings instead of a user_settings id.
- Deprecated `GET /api/v0/user/settings/location_list/` in favor of `GET /api/v0/user/settings/timezone_list/`

### v.0.7.2 (Compliance filter change)
- Changed email address separator for `action_details` in ComplianceFilter endpoints from a space (` `) to semicolon (`;`)
- This only affects compliance filter rules with the actions `2` (REDIRECT) or `4` (ADD BCC)

### v.0.7.1 (Email Preview additions)

- Added additional response parameter to `GET /api/v0/emails/preview/link/`:
  - `token`
- Removed deprecated endpoint `GET /api/v0/emails/preview/deliver/` in favor of `/api/v0/emails/preview/action/?action=deliver` 

### v.0.7.0 (M365 Backup integration)

- Added `/api/v0/cmc/m365backup/`
- Removed parameters from response of `GET /api/v0/cmc/vmbackup/`:
  - `msp_id`
  - `region`

### v.0.6.0 (VM Backup integration)

- Added `/api/v0/cmc/auth/`
- Added `/api/v0/cmc/vmbackup/`
- Added `/api/v0/cmc/manage/msp/`

### v.0.5.1 (Mailbox adjustments)

- Changed `/api/v0/mailboxes/`
  - Deprecated the `have_email_address` parameter

### v.0.5.0 (Outlook addin ATP endpoints)
- Added `/api/v0/emails/atp/result/`
- Added `/api/v0/emails/atp/upload/`
- Changed `/api/v0/emails/atp/status/`
  - Added field `token` for foreign uploaded emails

### v.0.4.0 (Access Tokens)

- Added `/api/v0/auth/access_token/`
- Added `/api/v0/auth/access_token/{token_id}`

### v.0.3.0 (Threat Live Monitoring)

- Added `/api/v0/atp/attack_map/`
- Added `/api/v0/atp/attempted_attacks/attack/`
- Added `/api/v0/atp/threat/attack_type/`
- Added `/api/v0/atp/threat/attack_vector/`
- Added `/api/v0/atp/threat/time_of_day/`
- Added `/api/v0/atp/url_rewriting/clicks_by_device/`
- Added `/api/v0/atp/url_rewriting/clicks_by_os/`
- Added `/api/v0/atp/url_rewriting/clicks_by_time/`
- Changed `/api/v0/user/format/`
    - Changed field `format_time` of response from single value to dictionary containing short and medium format
    - Changed field `format_date` of response from single value to dictionary containing short and medium format

### v.0.2.1

- Renamed field `primary_colour` to `primary_color` in the responses of the following endpoints
    - `/api/v0/whitelabeling/`
    - `/api/v0/whitelabeling/infos/`

### v.0.2.0 (Onboarding)

- Added `/api/v0/thirdparty/check_user_type/`
- Added `/api/v0/thirdparty/onboarding_redirect/`
- Added `/api/v0/thirdparty/o365/send_dns_settings/`
- Added `/api/v0/thirdparty/o365/authresult/`
- Added `/api/v0/thirdparty/o365/login_redirect/`
- Added `/api/v0/thirdparty/o365/msloginurl/`
- Added `/api/v0/thirdparty/o365/onboarding/`
- Added `/api/v0/thirdparty/o365/onboarding/status/`
- Added `/api/v0/thirdparty/o365/partner_link/`
- Added `/api/v0/thirdparty/o365/permission_link/`
- Added `/api/v0/thirdparty/o365/status/`
- Added `/api/v0/thirdparty/o365/uuid_validation/<uuid>/`
- Added `/api/v0/thirdparty/o365/resetdemodata/`


### v0.2.0 (Auditing)

- Added `/api/v0/auditing/_search/`
- Added `/api/v0/user/auditing_columns/`

### v0.1.0

- Moved `/api/login/` to `/api/auth/login/`
    - Renamed field `xobject_id` to `object_id` matching the use in other endpoints
- Moved `/api/logout/` to `/api/auth/logout/`
    - Changed request from GET to POST
- Moved `/api/pw_reset/` to `/api/password_reset/`
- Moved `/api/password_reset/` to `/api/password_reset/confirm/`
- Moved `/api/emails/atpscan/` to `/api/emails/atp/scan/`
- Moved `/api/emails/atpstatus/` to `/api/emails/atp/status`
- Moved `/api/user_settings` to `/api/user/settings/`
    - Remove `location_list` from GET and POST response
    - Rename `location.text` to `location.long`
- Added new endpoint `/api/user/settings/location_list/` for getting the location list removed from `/api/user/settings/`
    - Returns a list of {"id": <ID>, "long": <location name>} dictionaries
- Moved `/api/format/` to `/api/user/format/`
- Removed `/api/objects/` and added `/api/user/` as a replacement
    - Removed fields `children` and `children_count` from response
- Moved `/api/email_columns/` to `/api/user/email_columns/`
- Moved `/api/emails/preview/` to `/api/emails/header/`
    - Renamed field `raw_mail` to `raw_header`
- Changed response of `/api/emails/statistic/`
    - Previously a dictionary of ID -> count was returned
    - Now a list of dictionaries containing type, name and value (count) are returned
- Changed response of `/api/whitelabeling/infos/`
    - Renamed field `theme_color` to `primary_colour` to be more consistent
- Changed HTTP method of `/api/emails/black_white_list/` from PUT to POST to be in line with our guidelines
- Changed HTTP method of `/api/whitelabeling/` from PUT to POST to be in line with our guidelines

tags.name: ATP Subscription
tags.description:
Endpoints for activating and deactivating the ATP scan service for customers and configuring notification emails
which receive ATP real time alert emails.

tags.name: Access Token
tags.description:
Endpoints for creating, retrieving and revoking access tokens.

An access token can be used in scripts or other programs if you do not want to use your login credentials. Multiple
access tokens can be created. An access token can have a name and an expiration date. A lost or compromised access
token can be revoked.

An access token can be used the same way as a normal login token.

tags.name: Bulk User Import
tags.description:
Endpoints for bulk operations (insert, update, delete) on users. Together these operations can be used to
 synchronise users of a customer from an external source.

 The synchronise process should always start with a bulk delete operation. After the delete operation has finished
 the bulk insert and update operations can be executed. The execution order of the insert and update operations
 doesn't matter.

 ### Request Structure
 The request bodies of the bulk operations are structured in a similar fashion.
 The request object contains a field `data` which contains key-value pairs of customer name and the customer
 request properties.

 Here is an example request for an insert or update operation:

 ``` json
 {
     "data": {
         "testcustomer.de": {
             "users": [
                 {
                     "emails": [
                         "user1@testcustomer.de",
                         "alias1@testcustomer.de"
                     ],
                     "groups": ["Bobsleighing"]
                     "environment": "environmentname"
                     "forename": "Bob",
                     "surname": "Bobson",
                     "city": "Example Town",
                     "office": "Bobsleigh garage",
                     "homepage": "bobsleighing.example.com"
                 },
                 {
                     "emails": [
                         "user2@testcustomer.de",
                         "alias2@testcustomer.de"
                     ]
                 }
             ]
         },
         "othercustomer.com": {...}
     }
 }
 ```

 The `emails` field contains the list of of emails for a user. The first email in this list will be used as the
 primary email address of the user. The primary email address can be used to identify a user.

 There are also a lot of optional LDAP-related fields. Two importand ones are `forename` and `surname`, which are
 used by TFFF. All LDAP fields are ignored if SaD is activated.

 <details>
 <summary>Expand me for a list of all LDAP fields</summary>

 - `city`
 - `commonname`
 - `company`
 - `countrycode`
 - `department`
 - `description`
 - `displayname`
 - `email`
 - `employee`
 - `fax`
 - `forename`
 - `guid`
 - `homepage`
 - `homephone`
 - `imaddress`
 - `info`
 - `iptelephone`
 - `mobile`
 - `office`
 - `pager`
 - `postalcode`
 - `postofficebox`
 - `samaccountname`
 - `state`
 - `street`
 - `superior`
 - `surname`
 - `telephone`
 - `usnchanged`

 All string fields except for `employee` are limited to 255 characters.
 </details>


 `groups`, also optional, contains a list of group names. Currently only one group will be used. The used
 group is the first existing group the user can be assigned to.
 When calling:
 - `/create`
   - an empty list, or a list not containing any valid group has no effect.
 - `/update`
   - an empty list, or a list not containing any valid group, will remove the group assignment of the existing user.
   - if the list contains the already assigned group at any position, no changes will be made.


 ### Responses and Errors
 The bulk operations should not fail because of one problem with one user/customer. Therefore the operations always
 return a 200 OK response. To detect any errors you have to inspect the returned JSON. The customer object can
 contain `failed` and `error` fields. The `failed` field indicates that the whole import for this customer has
 failed. The `errors` field contains problematic users.

 ``` json
 {
     "data": {
         "testcustomer.de": {
             "errors": {
                 "user1@testcustomer.de": "ERROR_ENUM"
                 "user2@testcustomer.de": [{"alias2@testcustomer.de": "ERROR_ENUM"}]
             }
         },
         "othercustomer.com": {
             "failed": "Failed to import customer."
         },
     }
 }
 ```

 The example response indicates the following problems: The import for `othercustomer.com` failed completely.
 The user user1@testcustomer.de couldn't be imported. The alias email address alias2@testcustome.de couldn't be
 imported, but the user user2@testcustomer.de was created.

 Error Messages (ERROR_ENUM)

 ```
[DATA_INVALID : Passed data is invalid.]
[FAILED_TO_IMPORT : Customer data couldn't updated or inserted.]
[EMAIL_IS_NOT_VALID: Given E-Mail is not a valid E-Mail]
[DOMAIN_IS_NOT_VALID: Given domain is not valid]
[ALREADY_IN_USE: Given e-mail is already in use]
[UNKOWN_ERROR: Unknown Error occurred]
[USER_CREATION_FAILED: Mailbox couldn't created]
[DUPLICATE: Duplicate E-Mail Address in JSON Data found]
 ```

tags.name: O365 Migration
tags.description:
If a customer wants to migrate, the endpoints needs to be called in the following sequence:
1. Initiate Migration
2. Trigger a process to check if we got Micrsoft permissions for the tenant
3. O365 Sanity checks for migration (migration status needs to be 2000)
4. O365 confirmation of user equality (migration status needs to be 3000)
5. Run O365 migration (migration status needs to be 4000)

The migration status can be fetched with the endpoint: "Get Status of Initial Synchronization"

tags.name: Password Reset
tags.description:
The following operations cover the password reset process.

If a user has forgotten their password, they can
[request a new password](#operation/password_reset_post). An email will be sent containing the new
password and a confirmation link to the provided email address.

Here is an example for a password reset confirmation link:
`$HOST/reset/eyJ1aWQiOiA1ODYzMTEwNSwgInRva2VuIjogIjR4NS04Nzc1YTQzMzNhMzBmYTZjNTBjNSJ9`. It contains a base64
encoded JSON object of the following structure:

```
{
    uid: integer
    token: string
}
```

The `uid` represents the ID of the user for which the password reset was requested. The `token` is the confirmation
token to complete the reset.

The user can then confirm the password by POSTing the received JSON object to the [reset confirmation
endpoint](#operation/password_reset_confirm_post).

tags.name: Threat Live Monitoring
tags.description:
Several endpoints return statistics about attack emails. Most of these endpoints take `date_from` and `date_to`
parameters. These parameters cannot be older then a year and will be clamped to `now - 1 year` ago.
Additionally `date_from` and `date_to` need to be at least one hour apart.

tags.name: Whitelabeling
tags.description:
You can customize the Control Panel and emails sent by it to embed your companyâ€™s color, logo and favicon.
Simple / email customization can be done without any charges, but as soon as a domain is given
you will be billed for this feature.

The whitelabeling style consists of four primary parts:

1. **theme**, which influences the overall look of the Control Panel. This can be either dark or bright.
1. **primary color**, which is used throughout the Control Panel.
1. **logo**
1. **favicon**

The images are uploaded and returned as base64 encoded strings prefixed with their mimetype:
`<mimetype>;base64,<data>`.

endpoint can be called. The whitelabele style is only determined by the provided host header.

get.description:
Returns recent attack emails, their source, destination and type.
The optional parameter `date_from` should be used to prevent retrieving duplicate attack emails.
The workflow looks like this:

1. Initially call this endpoint without `date_from.`
2. Set `date_from` to the timestamp of the newest email in the last response on subsequent calls.

The returned list is sorted in descending order based on the timestamp of an attack email.

The attack email type can be one of the following:

- `attachment`, `attachment_downloader`, `attachment_dropper`, `attachment_packer`, `phishing`, `fraud`, `link`, `link_dropper`, `link_downloader`
- `trojan_horse`, `bot`, `spyware`, `point_of_sale`, `banker`, `root_kit`, `ransomware`, `miner`, `remote_access_trojan`, `backdoor`, `keylogger`
- `info`, `spam`, `content`, `threat`

parameters.name: object_id
parameters.description: The ID of an object. An object can be a user, customer or partner.

post.summary: Export auditing entries as CSV file
post.description:
To be exported auditing entries can be filtered the same way as in the auditing search endpoint. The export of
individual auditing entries is not supported.

The field `export_keys` can be used to select the to be exported columns for each auditing entry. The columns
`old_values` and `new_values` will **not** be exported.

In addition, `export_type` defines how the auditing entries are exported. Valid `export_type`s are:

| Export Type    | Meaning                                            |
|----------------|----------------------------------------------------|
| `download`     | Export of the whole table as downloadable CSV file |
| `email`        | Export of the whole table as email                 |

**Email export:** for export type `email` you have to provide an email address with field `email` to which the
export data will be send.

get.description:
Check if the authenticated user identified by the given token has the given permission on the given target.

- The `object_id` defines the target to check the permission on.
- The `permission` is the name of the permission to check.

This endpoint can't be used to check if _any_ user has a permission on a given target, you can only use it to
check the permission for the requesting user.

The response will be empty in any case, except if the given session identifier is invalid.

On creation, every argument is required.

### Available choices for `forbidden_attachment_handling`

| Value | Description                          |
|:------|:-------------------------------------|
|0      | Block matching emails                |
|1      | Cut attachments from matching emails |

(Value `1` can not be set for outgoing settings. It will always be `0` for outgoing settings.)

post.description:
The same arguments are needed as for the email search.

In addition, `export_type` and `export_keys` have been added for the actual export.

Valid `export_type`s are:

| Export Type    | Meaning                                  |
|----------------|------------------------------------------|
| `download`     | Export of the whole table as download    |
| `row_download` | Export of selected row(s) as download    |
| `email`        | Export of the whole table as email       |
| `row_email`    | Export of selected row(s) as email       |

<mark>**! Important !:** </mark> To export only selected rows you have to set the `mail_list` parameter
(see the request example). To export the selected columns you have to set the `export_key` parameter.

**Email-Export:** To send the exported csv-file via email your `export_type` must be set to `row_email` or
`email` and you have to set the `email` parameter with an email address of your choice.

post.description:
The maximum number of receivable results for one search query is *10.000*.
If more results are available, the `has_more_elements` is set to `true`.
This indicates that the search query should be more specific.
Thus the sum of `offset` and `limit` should never exceed 10.000.
A validation error is returned if it does.

Keep in mind that 10.000 is just a theoretical limit.
To ensure the request is successful, we recommend lower limits (like 2.000) for individual requests.

The **ISO-8601 and UTC (YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ)** for the dates are **with applied timezones**.
This applies to both **request and response**.

### `direction`: The direction ID is defined as:

| ID | Meaning  |
|----|----------|
| 1  | Incoming |
| 2  | Outgoing |

### `crypt_type_in` & `crypt_type_out`: Encryption IDs with their corresponding names.

| ID | Name    |
|----|---------|
| 1  | NONE    |
| 2  | WEBSAFE |
| 3  | SMIME   |
| 4  | PGP     |
| 5  | EMIG    |
| 6  | DANE    |
| 7  | TLS     |

### `classification`: The classification of an email.

| ID | Name      |
|----|---------- |
| 1  | SPAM      |
| 2  | CLEAN     |
| 3  | REJECTED  |
| 5  | THREAT    |
| 8  | CONTENT   |
| 11 | INFOMAIL  |
| 12 | ADVTHREAT |

### `status`: The delivery status of an email.

| ID | Name      |
|----|-----------|
| 0  | No Status |
| 1  | Delivered |
| 2  | Deferred  |
| 3  | Rejected  |

### Valid `size` units are

| Unit | Description |
|------|-------------|
| `kb` | Kilobyte    |
| `mb` | Megabyte    |
| `gb` | Gigabyte    |

### Available `size` operators are

| Value | Meaning      |
|-------|--------------|
| `gt`  | greater than |
| `lt`  | less than    |
| `eq`  | equal to     |

### Action taken during email processing. The available `last_remediation_actions` values are:

- "move_banner"
- "hard_delete"
- "soft_delete"
- "no_action"
- "move"
- "banner"
- "quarantine"
- "tag"

post.summary: Export Deny- or Allowlist Entries of an Object
post.description:
In addition, `export_type` have been added for the actual export.

Valid `export_type`s are:

| Export Type    | Meaning                                  |
|----------------|------------------------------------------|
| `download`     | Export of the whole table as download    |
| `email`        | Export of the whole table as email       |

**Mail-Export:** To send the exported csv-file via mail your `export_type` must be `email` and you have to set
the `email` param with an email address of your choice.

### Exported columns

The exported columns are:

#### Available for all lists

- `value`: It may contain domains, email addresses or IP addresses.
- `description`: A piece of descriptive information about the entry.
- `owner`: It may contain the primary domain or any end-user email address.

#### Available only for the customer allowlist

- `entry_type`: Possible values are: `EMAIL` (email address), `DOMAIN` (domain name), `IP` (IP address), and
`URL` (URL).
- `spam_protection`: Possible values are: `0` (do not bypass the filter), `1` (bypass the filter).
- `content_filter`: Possible values are: `0` (do not bypass the filter), `1` (bypass the filter).
- `malware_protection`: Possible values are: `0` (do not bypass the filter), `1` (bypass the filter).
- `phishing_protection`: Possible values are: `0` (do not bypass the filter), `1` (bypass the filter).
- `sender_validation`: Possible values are: `0` (do not bypass the filter), `1` (bypass the filter).
- `email_freezing`: Possible values are: `0` (do not bypass the filter), `1` (bypass the filter).
- `atp_url_rewriting`: Possible values are: `0` (do not bypass the filter), `1` (bypass the filter).
- `atp_tfff`: Possible values are: `0` (do not bypass the filter), `1` (bypass the filter).
- `atp_tfff_related_user`: Possible values are: empty or any end-user email address.
- `atp_url_rewriting_include_subdomains`: Possible values are: `0` (do not include subdomains for values used
for the URL-rewriting filter), `1` (include subdomains).

The **ISO-8601 and UTC (YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ)** for the dates refer to the **applied timezones**.
This applies to both **request and response**.

### `direction`: The direction ID is defined as:

| ID | Meaning  |
|----|----------|
| 1  | Incoming |
| 2  | Outgoing |

### `crypt_type_in` & `crypt_type_out`: Encryption IDs with their corresponding names.

| ID | Name    |
|----|---------|
| 1  | NONE    |
| 2  | WEBSAFE |
| 3  | SMIME   |
| 4  | PGP     |
| 5  | EMIG    |
| 6  | DANE    |
| 7  | TLS     |

### `classification`: The classification of an email.

| ID | Name      |
|----|---------- |
| 1  | SPAM      |
| 2  | CLEAN     |
| 3  | REJECTED  |
| 5  | THREAT    |
| 8  | CONTENT   |
| 11 | INFOMAIL  |
| 12 | ADVTHREAT |

### `status`: The delivery status of an email.

| ID | Name      |
|----|-----------|
| 0  | No Status |
| 1  | Delivered |
| 2  | Deferred  |
| 3  | Rejected  |

### Valid `size` units are

| Unit | Description |
|------|-------------|
| `kb` | Kilobyte    |
| `mb` | Megabyte    |
| `gb` | Gigabyte    |

### Available `size` operators are

| Value | Meaning      |
|-------|--------------|
| `gt`  | greater than |
| `lt`  | less than    |
| `eq`  | equal to     |

**Mail-Export:** To send the exported csv-file via mail your `export_type` must be `row_email` or `email` and you

have to set the `email` param with an email address of your choice.

post.description:
Returns a list of mailboxes for the given `object_id`.

Mailboxes can be filtered based on the `name`, `type` and `environment` and attributes.

### Available mailbox types

| ID | Description |
|----|-------------|
`0` | INTERNAL_USER
`1` | INTERNAL_CALENDAR
`2` | INTERNAL_ROOM
`3` | INTERNAL_FORWARD
`4` | O365_POSTBOX
`5` | O365_FUNCTIONAL
`6` | O365_ADMIN
`7` | LDAP
`8` | CP_ADMIN
`9` | O365_SHARED_MAILBOX
`10` | O365_DISTRIBUTION_LIST
`11` | FOREIGN

delete.description:
A single mailbox can be deleted by providing its id with query parameter `mailbox_id`. Multiple
mailboxes can be deleted at once by providing a list of mailbox ids in the request body. Note that in the latter
case **ALL** mailbox ids have to belong to the same customer! This constraint is enforced for performance
reasons. If mailboxes belong to different customers, you have to create a request for **EACH** customer.

Both modes are distinguished by the presence of query parameter `mailbox_id`. With query parameter `mailbox_id`
present the request body will always be ignored.

| `row_download` | Export of selected row(s) as download    |
| `email`        | Export of the whole table as email       |

<mark>**! Important !:** </mark> To export only selected rows you have to set the `mailbox_list` param
(look at example request).

To export selected columns you have to set the `export_key` param.

**Mail-Export:** To send the exported csv-file via mail your `export_type` must be `row_email` or `email` and
you have to set the `email` param with an email address of your choice.

A "domain foreign mailbox" is a mailbox with a domain that is not part of the parents domains like "@gmail.com".
These users can only login through the noLogin feature and are restricted in their functionality in the CP.
E.g. they will not have their email traffic displayed in the control panel and other mail related features
will not work for them (compliance filter rules, allow- & denylists, etc).
But they can be assigned as customer admins for different customers to manage those.
Requires special permission.

post.description:
The parameter `ttl` can be used to specify a lifespan for the newly created token. The lifespan counts from the
point the token was created. It can either specified as total seconds, or with the following notation:

`[DD] [HH:[MM:]]ss[.uuuuuu]`.

Because of backwards compatibility the `ttl` parameter is not required. If its not specified, these tokens will be
valid until deleted, which should be seen as bad practice from now on.

Tokens will be deleted automatically if they are either expired (if previously created with a TTL) or successfully
used with the `auth/nologin/` or `one_way_token/validate/` endpoint.

post.description:
With this endpoint it is possible to define custom durations for the authentication token lifetime of
_all users_ of the specified target (customer). The lifetime is calculated in minutes of inactivity after it
was last used. It **does not** define the lifetime after creation!

This only affects authentication tokens which are provided by the login methods. API access tokens are not
affected by this setting.

The system default (with no custom settings defined) is 24 hours.

The duration can be customized or turned off completely if `duration` is set to 0.
If set to the equivalent of 24 hours, settings are reset to system default.

get.description:
Get the status of the initial Office 365 synchronization.

**Return parameters explained:**

- `user` and `domains` are integers representing the amount of synchronized users or domains.
- `status` represents the status of the synchronization process. Can be one of
    `progress`, `success` or `failed`.
- `state` is the onboarding state explained in the table below.
- `test_until` is the timestamp the active test stage ends.
- `bundle` is the bundle type as string.
- `license_count` the maximum license count for current month.

### The `state` is represented by integers:

| int | Description |
|:---:|:------------|
        | `-1` | Waiting For Microsoft Permission |
| `-0.5` | Tenant Already Exists |
| `0` | Start Onboarding |
| `0.5` | Check Tpeb Requirements |
| `1` | Fetch Domains |
| `2` | Fetch Delta |
| `3` | Fetch Groups |
| `4` | Fetch Admins |
| `4.5` | Fetch Users |
| `5` | Write Domains |
| `6` | Delete Users |
| `6.1` | Update Users |
| `6.2` | Write Users |
| `6.5` | Write Groups |
| `7` | Write Settings |
| `7.5` | Sync Apps |
| `8` | Fast Sync |
| `9` | Mx Record Check |
| `10` | Active Test |
| `11` | Bought |

### The `bundle` parameter can be one of the following values:

| Value | Description |
|:-----:|:------------|
        | `TPB` | Business |
| `TPE` | Enterprise |
| `TPEB` | Enterprise Backup |
| `BS` | Basic Sync |
| `EEP` | EEP |
| `TP4` | Compliance and Awareness |
| `TP4N` | 365 Total Protection Plan 4 |

post.description:
this is a 'proxy' endpoint that will forward a request to teams protection services

This allow to have only one 'public' point on the architecture (security concerns), and only
one component responsible for authroization and authentication => the cp.

That's why there is no serializer here. The CP has no reason to validate the request payload
because that is already handled by the underlying teams protection service that will receive
the request.

get.description:
After the successful login and authorization on the Microsoft site, the user is redirected to the Control Panel.
Any redirection URL must be added to the Microsoft management interface. Adding every whitelabeled domain to that list would be a massive
overhead.

To avoid that, the user is always redirected to this API endpoint on the `cloud-security.de` domain, regardless
of which whitelabeled domain the user comes from. This domain points to our live instance of the Control Panel.

This API endpoint retrieves the correct whitelabeling URL and redirects the user depending on the domain they come from.

The possible redirection endpoints are:
- `/thirdparty/office365/sync/status`
- `/o365/external_sync`
- `/thirdparty/encryption/`
- `/email_security/atp`
- `/email_security/email_livetracking`

parameters.name: state
parameters.description: The serialized state from Microsoft.

parameters.name: APP-ID
parameters.description: A unique identifier specific to your app issued by us.

302.description: Redirect to the regarding whitelabeling URL.

400.description: Probably an invalid state.

500.description: An unexpected internal server error occured.

query.title: Query
query.description:
May contains eq, match, range operator for elastic search query like :

- "query: {"match": {"url": "some.url"}}
- "query": {"range": {"date": {"gte": "2020-03-06T15:34:16+01:00", "lte": "2021-03-16T15:34:16+01:00"}}}

Eq is for strict equality, match for a "contains" search.
Theses operators may be combined with "and" and "or" :

"query": {"or": [{"match": {"url": "some.url"}}, {"match": {"url": "other.url"}}]}

available fields for eq:
- verdict

available fields for match:
- from
- to
- url
- verdict

available fields for range:
- date

result.title: Result
result.description:
The result has the form of:
{
    "result": {
        "total": 1,
        "messages": [
            {
                "id": "some-id",
                "date": "2025-02-06T15:34:16+01:00",
                "from": {"id": "user-id-1", "email": "becassine@breiz.fr"},
                "to": [{"id": "user-id-2", "email": "louis.mandrin@dauphine.fr"}],
                "urls": [{"value": "https://malicious.us/some/path", "verdict": "phishing"}],
                "domains": ["malicious.us"],
                "chat_id": "some-chat-id",
                "channel_id": "",
                "channel_teams_id": "",
                "conversation_type": "chat",
                "conversation_name": "",
                "chat_type": "OneOne",
                "channel_type": "",
                "is_read": true
            },
        ]
    }
}
